content.description: Stand start on the northeast arete with whatever hands suit your fancy.  It won't matter much what hands you start with, as the problem is basically a glorified ladder.  Nonetheless, the fact that it gets you more than a few feet off the deck might make worth your while.  On the other hand, it is so easy, you might not really feel like your high up at all.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter.  There is a rock behind the starting area that you wouldn't want to tumble into if you fell, but falling typically shouldn't be an issue on this climb.
content.location: This problem is located on the boulder's northeast arete.  It's a pretty sharp corner, so it's hard to miss.  A rock and a tree sit a few feet from the problem's start.

content.description:
Start hands matched on a good lip--which is unfortunately hard to see in the beta photo--and get your feet on.  Move up and left to a good juggy crimp.  From there, move up through a dish and scattered good holds.

If you're only going to climb one of these problems, do this one.  If you climb the intended line, the first couple moves are pretty fun.
content.protection: A pad.  Also a spotter if you're worried about flying it the bush underneath the problem.
content.location: This problem starts with to the right of the little tree with on the plate/lip feature above the bottom right corner of the tiny roof feature on the boulder's east face.

content.description: Start with you left on a sidepull, your right on a good lip, and your feet on a great, low ledge.  Move straight up and slightly left up a seam of sidepulls.
content.protection: Pad.  The landing is flat and free from rocks, so not much to worry about.
content.location: If you are looking at the east slabby face, this route starts left of the small tree next to the boulder's tiny roof feature.

content.description: Start with your right on a side-pull ledge and your left on another side pull of your choosing.  Move up and slightly left through a big dish feature, then straight up to the top.
content.protection: A pad.  The finish is fairly high, so a spotter would be helpful too.  The landing is flat and free of rocks.
content.location:
This problem starts to the right of the small tree and sits between

The Scapula

and

The Spine

.

content.description: Start with your left on a good lip and your right on a nice crimp.  Move straight up.  Though you can't really see it in the photos, about halfway up the rock there is a shelf that moves up and left.  You can follow the shelf up and left to finish or just use it to top out straight up.  It doesn't really matter as the climb is over by the time you get you get to the shelf anyway.
content.protection: A pad.  The landing is flat and free of rocks.  If you top out by moving up and right, don't fall onto the little tree.  That will probably hurt.
content.location:
If you are looking at the boulder's east face, this route starts just to the left of the little tree.  It starts just barely to the right of

Patella

.  The two problems share a start hold.
